I'm a librarian and I've added probably 300+ books and editions over the years. I regret it massively.
They have some sort of a bot that recently decided some of my contributions are "not books" and automatically deleted them. They also automatically import garbage data from Amazon, resulting in DVDs and other random crap in the database, and especially tons of "Forgotten Books" editions (ripped from Google Books) with horrible typos.
(Not even counting the garbage that was added to the database by random users and other librarians who seem too stupid to wipe their own ass, or the abysmally bad redesign that - besides being ugly and clumsy - hides useful data.)
To me that was a clear sign how worthless I am to the site. They don't even just let me hang around, they outright made a program to ruin what I add and automatically import more garbage without having a single human check it beforehand. They clearly don't want me as a human contributor, and so I stopped using the site almost entirely. Going to delete my profile, and make a new one just to follow a few IRL friends.

posts.sub: did trainspotting speak to anyone on a deeper level
posts.com:
i was only like 15 when i decided to read some 600 page book written in scottish brogue, but something about it really hit home in a way i havent felt before or since ive read heart of darkness.

theres multiple facets to it: drugs, depression, the streets, how uncaring society is, medical abuse, the basic human condition, angst and hate and rage at the life were expected to live. the modernity of it, still relevant today, is what grabbed me as opposed to something more antiquated.

what really gets me is after i read it i started doing heroin years later. i would get into situations or dialogue that would be verbatim from the book. i realized how true to life it is, but you dont know unless youve seen this stuff play out. just a lot of weird idiosyncrasies with that scene but intertwined with some brutal examination of the truth of everyones lives in the modern day.

i read it 15 years ago now (only once) and i still think about it all of the time. it just felt like there was so much truth encapsulated in a book which, on the surface, seems like a sensationalist trashy movie pitch about how cool drugs are and why parents sucks because they make you do chores. its like a gestalt or some shit.

am i the only one?

>inb4 some pretentious shit about w.s.b.

>>21479559
>Welsh has been diminishing returns since
as far as im concerned hes a one and done but i think he really touched on something ineffable in this. although it is a collection of short stories they form a cohesive vision of bleakness. the landscape is bleak, the weather is bleak, jobs are bleak, life is bleak. soulless, consumerist, crushing, suffocating which is accentuated by these being the defining qualities of northern scotland.

its a book of no hope and no future, but its not nihilistic entirely either. its just a documentation on the true state of affairs of our reality now.

>Has any American novel managed to convey the opioid thing as well as Welsh does the British equivalent?
some would argue, but i dont think anything i know of comes close. not just the heroin use, but other drugs and the lifestyle in general. even dealing with the emergency room or government job programs designed to fail. this coupled with the outlook on life by the narrators and their environmental reality shows clearly not only how someone can be led to this existence, but how the rest of us are not much better off, maybe worse.

>“There are among us daylight ghosts, devoured by their absence, for whom life is one long aside. They walk our streets with muffled steps, and look at no one. No anxiety can be discovered in their eyes, no haste in their gestures. For them an outside world has ceased to exist, and they submit to every solitude. Careful to keep their distance, solicitous of their detachment, they inhabit an undeclared universe situated somewhere between the memory of the unimaginable and the imminence of certainty. Their smile suggests a thousand vanquished fears, the grace that triumphs over all things terrible: such beings can pass through matter itself. Have they overtaken their own origins? Discovered in themselves the very sources of light? No defeat, no victory dis turbs them. Independent of the sun, they are self-sufficient: illuminated by Death.”

-Cioran, The Temptation to Exist

The creation of a new publishing company

Hi everyone, I had an idea. What if we had an imprint for ideas that people won’t publish anymore in the mainstream literature field? And perhaps the best way to collect and distribute this writing would be by subscription, like they did back in the 18th century; that’s how the founding fathers got their books. I really see it as quite the tragedy that we don’t have any sincerity these days, and I think we should. Perhaps a new imprint could be a viable sense of permanence to what’s currently flirting around the edges of society with podcasts, telegram groups, and urbit meetups. Regardless of how digital we are, we still need to touch things; to feel things and read them with our eyes to trust them. I think there are a lot of advanced things going on in NYC right now and I’d be happy to see us succeed in making a statement for literature. That way, we can finally crown a new sincere right for the world, rather than liars and jokers like Delillo Pynchon and DFW.

Do you guys think it would stand a chance? Or is the literary world not ready for it yet?

posts.com:
The original 6 by Margaret Weiss and Tracy Hickman, that is the Dragons of Autumn twilight cycle, and the Time of the Twins cycle, will forever be a series of books that I hold in high regard, even above Tolkien. The story of Raistlin in particular is wonderful, as it answers the question of "what can save an evil man?" It makes a convincing argument for it, too, because Raistlin receives all sorts of love that he doesn't really deserve. He receives brotherly love from his twin, the friendship of Tass, and Tanis, and all the others, and he receives the romantic attentions of a priestess, and he drags them all down and lessens them as a result. Raistlin's ultimate redemption comes from himself. He has to experience empathy, the realization that he is not the ultimate victim of life, and that there are so many other, less malevolent and more downtrodden people that he will hurt in his quest for power.

As for Forgotten Realms? Anything that R.A Salvatore wasn't involved in is kinda lame. Dude's a modern Robert E. Howard, and Drizzt is just a great character. Elminster can suck it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21473898
AI doesn't grow up in the environment humans grow up in, and art is a reflection of this environment. AI imitates human products of reflecting upon their environment, but cannot connect them to it. In a sense, AI usage of words is all context, namely the context of how humans use them - but not the non-verbal experiences they signify. It remains to be seen how 'original' AI can make its utterings look, but it has few consequences for art because that depends on sharing the human experience with the artist.

It has stopped moving forward. Name one discovery in the past 40 years that has changed our lives. Internet doesn't count, since it's just applied use of electrical currents and miniaturization.
All the scientific building blocks stopped being discovered with the mid-late 20th century, or if they were discovered recently (yay CERN), they were not practically applicable. The computer that runs AI is still the same as the one Turing came up with, just using more aggregate knowledge and trade experience.
If you knew anything about computation, you would know that modern architecture just can't replicate anything near human complexity. Even the most advanced algorithms are at best operating on the physical level of unicellular organisms (using just a paltry number of servers asynchronously to run it). The last big effort was the Human Genome Project, which was dead-ended because experimentation and research there was uninteresting to those with the means to use it.
Arguably social manipulation saw the greatest leap forward in the past decades, but the use of it is underwhelming for any kind of progress.
Teslas still use archaic batteries, just trumped up and tweaked so they're not an outright joke. And... yeah that's it, that's all the technological progress anyone might point to. Fucking tweaked Lithium-ion batteries.

Meanwhile the cult leaders are afraid of angry AI.

It is real art. You are just too pretentious to acknowledge the obvious twofold meaning of Art in English. Art is used both as a catch all term for visual media (paintings, drawings, murals etc) as well as a catch all term for craft (including other things like martial arts written arts architectural arts liberal arts). A thing appreciated and a thing created. These are two distinct categories. That can, but are not necessarily, one in the same.

This is a linguistic hang up more then anything. That English wound up using the broad term for craft for visual media as well.

Ted K's takes on the Fermi's Paradox is just a small part of the book. This guy is not taking into consideration a number of things.

We valuate our economy on financial indicators and companies are only saveguarding against the dangers coming from this sector.
However, the problem is that economy is not finantial, but energetic. Money is meaningless and all that matters is energy. And we have many kinds of energy to consider: physiological energy needs (calories), supply chain energy needs (fuel and electricity) and finally industrial energy needs (raw materials)
All three types of energy are scarse and depends on the other. All three of them are finite (even calories, since it depends on fertilizers in order to produce calorie-rich food)

Kaczynski is not the best guy laying out the industrial scarcity question, many other thinkers have put it in consideration. Kaczynski is tackling another important issue: the problem that industrial society leads to the denial of humanity and takes freedom away slice by slice.

Nietzsche's famous quotes on Parsifal were all written when he had only read the libretto of the opera and hadn't heard the music. He heard the overture to Parsifal sometime later and wrote to a friend something along the lines of "compared to this, all other music sounds like a mistake."

He had a personal falling out with Wagner and Parsifal provided a handy excuse. In fact, the shocking thing is that Nietzsche, if he were consistent, should've chosen to break with Wagner at the time of Tristan, not Parsifal. Tristan being Wagner's first completely serious Schopenhauerian opera

Tristan is the perfect dramatic adaptation of Gottfried's poem. It is entirely in the spirit of that work.

>I, too, felt driven to this "Whence and Wherefore?" and for long it banned me from the magic of my art. But my time of penance taught me to overcome the question. All doubt at last was taken from me when I gave myself up to the Tristan. Here, in perfect trustfulness, I plunged into the inner depths of soul-events, and from the inmost centre of the world I fearlessly built up its outer form. A glance at the volumen of this poem will show you at once that the exhaustive detail-work which a historical poet is obliged to devote to clearing up the outward bearings of his plot, to the detriment of a lucid exposition of its inner motives, I now trusted myself to apply to these latter alone. Life and death, the whole import and existence of the outer world, here hang on nothing but the inner movements of the soul. The whole affecting Action comes about for reason only that the inmost soul demands it, and steps to light with the very shape foretokened in the inner shrine.
- Wagner

Allow me to present the poem used in my younger brother’s eight grade English class:

Caroline

By Allison Joseph


In the eighth grade, we teased that girl
as much as we could, mocking

her clothes, her stringy hair
her flat, pallid face that revealed

little protest. Used to being
the one white girl in our class

of blacks, Hispanics, she endured
our taunts on her lack of rhythm,

on her stiff, flat-butted walk.
How we pitied her—brown hair

parted straight, pulled back
in a dull ponytail, her jeans

or corduroy pants in washed-out
shades of gray or blue,

her homework neatly done
in pained, legible print.

How weak it was to be white,
we thought, not able to dance

or run fast, to have skin
that peeled from too much sun.

We never let Caroline forget
that she was white and we

were black, that we could
swing our hips and snap

our fingers without trying,
privy to street-slang rhythms.

But she was our white girl,
and if anyone else dared
to touch her or call her names
we’d be on them in a second,

calling them ugly right back,
slapping offenders if necessary.

With one of us by her side,
she could walk the school

safely, knowing she was ours
even if we didn’t let her in

all the way, even if we laughed
at her white speech, thin lips.

posts.com:
>>21475826
That brings up an interesting path of inquiry. But then are we potentially anthropomorphizing the ocean again in a manner we should not? The question is raised more than once whether the ocean can even have a concept of plurality, or of the existence of other conscious organisms. I think to Kelvin's working theory that he discusses with Snaut at the end of the novel, the emphasis and import he places in the fact that, unlike us, the ocean's actions cannot have a purpose beyond what the ocean itself creates (or at least could not until it "discovered" us).

What was sent in the original X-ray bombardment (not somebody's consciousness I assume), and why did it provoke the appearance of the g-formations? Why can't the g-formations be apart from their "hosts"? This might be evidence in favor of your theory, as it might be evidence of the recognition of distinct individual conscious entities outside of itself. But who knows? I think now to that dream I mentioned earlier, it's timing (after the consciousness bombardment), the notion that the two parties only discover themselves and not the other through the contact. But was that the important contact, the best that could be done? The first step? The g-formations stop afterwards.

I dunno, I'm rambling and probably overthinking it. Lem seemed to like to talk about the impossibility of communication. But what a great book. There's a ton to discuss. I'll have to re-read it soon while all my questions are still fresh.

posts.com:
Is the William Cullen Bryant translation actually good? I am thinking of copping the edition sold by /ourguys/ over at Imperium Press (mainly to read the Ricardo Duchesne foreword) but haven't heard much about this particular translation.

IP says:
> W.C. Bryant’s verse translation has been acclaimed for over a century, rendering Homer’s hexameter into the epic metre of our own “manly and flexible tongue”. In Bryant’s sublime blank verse, Homer’s winged words take flight, never surpassed but in the Greek for grace and power.

True? Everyone shills other translations.

Ian Johnston take is:
> Bryant makes clear that his translation seeks to be “strictly faithful” and at the same time to offer “no violence to the ordinary usages and structures of our own.” He continues, “I have sought to attain what belongs to the original,—a fluent narrative style, which shall carry the reader forward without the impediment of unexpected inversions and capricious phrases. . . .” This admirable goal informs the translation throughout, which is clear, fast paced, and for the most part accurate (like many others Bryant is not entirely sure about Homeric epithets). His translation lacks the sense, so common in many nineteenth-century renderings of Homer (and some modern ones), of a verse line stuffed or wrenched to meet the demands of some metrical arrangement which the translator has determined is more important than fluent, idiomatic English. Bryant’s Iliad ranks as one of the most successful and readable English renditions of Homer of the century.

>Rudyard Kipling is one of the best-known of the late Victorian poets and story-tellers. Although he was awarded the Nobel Prize for literature in 1907, his political views, which grew more toxic as he aged, have long made him critically unpopular. In the New Yorker, Charles McGrath remarked “Kipling has been variously labelled a colonialist, a jingoist, a racist, an anti-Semite, a misogynist, a right-wing imperialist warmonger; and—though some scholars have argued that his views were more complicated than he is given credit for—to some degree he really was all those things. That he was also a prodigiously gifted writer who created works of inarguable greatness hardly matters anymore, at least not in many classrooms, where Kipling remains politically toxic.” However, Kipling’s works for children, above all his novel The Jungle Book, first published in 1894, remain part of popular culture through the many movie versions made and remade since the 1960s.

posts.com: Hey /lit/, what works of modern and/or medieval philosophy would you recommend for someone interested in reading French postmodernists like Deleuze and Foucault? I am very well acquainted with ancient philosophy up to Plotinus and the other Neoplatonists but have only barely stepped into medieval and modern philosophy beyond introductory courses on each era. Any recommended writers or helpful introductory resources are appreciated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For Deleuze at the very least, the extent of medieval philosophy you would need would be better assumed through simply reading his 'Spinoza: Expressionism in Philosophy', as that is his most extended analysis of various medieval themes and his Spinozist spin on them. You can then look more closely at whichever ones you take a particular interest in within that work - Scotus is an obvious example, but also Eckhart, Dionysius, Eriugena, and Cusa. You could also read de Gandillac, one of his teachers whom he got most of his understanding of medieval philosophy from. As for modern philosophy, the obvious ones would be Spinoza, Kant, Hegel, Nietszche, and Bergson. Marx too if you are interested in his collaboration with Guattari.

For Foucault, I have little knowledge unfortunately.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21481709
Well no translation can really do that. The basic way to view the three most popular translations is
>Lattimore: most accurate (meaning literal translation of words), least poetic
>Fitzgerald: most poetic, least accurate
>Fagles: 50/50
If you are looking for something closest to the experience of hearing epic poetry sung, you will probably prefer Fitzgerald over Fagles, but both are good. Stay away from Lattimore. And I haven't read Fitzgerald's Odyssey so I have no idea if it's as good as his Iliad.

Actual criticism here. Nietzsche's take on ascetism being the will to power fulfilled by being turned inwards is inconsistent with the ascetic experience as described by the mystics, which is calm and serenity, compared to how the will to power fulfilled towards the outside world universally manifests itself as egotistical conquer and debauchery.

"Be that as it may, one has the general impression that, in the present state of things, there is no longer any stability; but while there are some who sense the danger and try to react to it, most of our contemporaries are quite at ease amid this confusion, in which they see a kind of exteriorized image of their own mentality. Indeed there is an exact correspondence between a world where everything seems to be in a state of mere 'becoming', leaving no place for the changeless and the permanent, and the state of mind of men who find all reality in this 'becoming', thus implicitly denying true knowledge as well as the object of that knowledge, namely transcendent and universal principles. One can go even further and say that it amounts to the negation of all real knowledge whatsoever, even of a relative order, since, as we have shown above, the relative is unintelligible and impossible without the absolute, the contingent without the necessary, change without the unchanging, and multiplicity without unity; 'relativism' is self-contradictory, for, in seeking to reduce everything to change, one logically arrives at a denial of the very existence of change; this was fundamentally the meaning of the famous arguments of Zeno of Elea."

>>21478790
I finished reading this book and I think it's superior to its film adaptation, even if slightly. There's more dialogue and details that explain some things better. There's also some relevant quotes that I don't know why weren't included in the film:

>"What do you say to a man that by his own admission has no soul?" Sheriff Bell
>"Somewhere out there is a true and living prophet of destruction and I dont want to confront him. I know he's real. I have seen his work. I walked in front of those eyes once. I wont do it again." Sheriff Bell
>"Anyway, you never know what worse luck your bad luck has saved you from." Uncle Ellis
>"Even a nonbeliever might find it useful to model himself after God." Anton Chigurh

The book's structure allows you to understand Sheriff Bell's life better. In every chapter there is a narration by him and it never gets old. We even learn what happened to him in the war.

There's a parallel that it's absent in the film that I found peculiar. When Moss is wounded after a shootout, he asks to some young men in the street to sell him one of the coats they're wearing. After they refuse he basically begs them to sell him a coat until one of them does (this is the scene in the film with the norteño band). On the other hand when Chigurh is wounded after the car accident, two young men happen to be near there, Chigurh offers money for a t-shirt and one of them voluntarily gives it to him for free, he then insists in paying them.

Another important difference is that in the film Carla Jean refuses to call it when Chigurh tosses the coin. While in the book he's there to kill her but decides to give her another chance with the coin toss, which she calls heads but was tails, in the very final moments she accepts her destiny.

We learn that Carson Wells worked once with Chigurh, and the reason why Chigurgh was handcuffed at the begining of the film is that a man insulted him and he killed him in a parking lot, later he allowed the deputy to detain him so he could "extricate himself by an act of will" (basically getting himself in trouble only to prove himself he could get out of it). There's also more details on what exactly happened in the war to Sheriff Bell and why he feels so guilty about it.

Overall it was a pretty good read even after having seen the film. And yes, they're basically the same but the small differences is what made the book better in my view. "And then I woke up."

The Red Book by Jung (I talk about the 200+ $ version) has two important parts
1. The first "half" of the book is Jung going full autism with his writing style. This also includes all the pictures
2. The second half is more or less just the text rewritten in a normal font

The whole "secret" of Jung is more or less just an IQ filter. Jung shows in his Red Book how to create your inner paradise and make it as real as the real world, including creating your inner waifu.
The problem is Jung is impossible to understand if you don't have an inner voice. Only if you have an inner voice, you can actually go the next step and start exploring your inner world and change it with the help of the Red Book.

The reason why Jung never wanted to release his book was because he couldn't visit the inner world of other people. When he realized that other people would just call him a shizo if he talks about his inner world, he rather chose to not allow the publicizing of his books.

I'm glad that the book was finally released, because now I have Jung's inner paradise can two parallel worlds. The sad part is that it sounds shizo and retards only know those shizo who say "my inner voice told me to kill" and other bullshit.
Jung is the exact opposite. You don't have an inner voice that tells you what to do, you have a parallel world you can visit whenever you want, even with eyes open. There is no one telling you how to behave, but you can create pretty much anything inside this world. You can even visit this world if you sleep, though this is insanely tough to do.
I wish I had more free time, because going on adventures and literally slaying dragons in your "shizo world" is comfy.

As a side note, if you are able to understand Jung, you have no psychological problem anymore, because the "shizo world" is your Psyche and your Self.

I would say any IQ below 180 makes it nearly impossible to actually visit in a quantum physical way your inner world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21481422
Found this somewhere
1. Memories, Dreams, Reflections - A great introduction to the personal life of Jung, and the experiences that influenced him
2. Man and His Symbols - A lighter introduction
3. Erich Neumann - The Origins and History of Consciousness - The first half is very accessible, second half might be something you come back to later.
4. Archetypes of the Collective Unconscious - This is where you start to go "oh... shit"
5. The Red Book - A very deep introduction to Carl Jung's inner life via his personal journals (supplement with Stephen Hoeller's lectures on the book)
6. Emma Jung and Marie-Louise von Franz - The Grail Legend - Ties in nicely with these next few books.
7. Answer to Job (and then Nietzsche's Antichrist)
8. Aion - You'll be as perplexed as you are terrified.
9. Psychology and Alchemy - [shrug]
10. Mysterium Coniunctionis
I personally did:
Man and His Symbols -> Aion -> The Red Book -> Answer to Job -> Mysterium Conunctionis

posts.com: I want to read Don Quixote romantically, as a vast existential drama depicting the idealist search for wisdom in a corporeal world, but Cervantes scholarship is getting in my way. Most of them claim that the romantic interpretation of the novel was a European invention which does not reflect either the intentions of the author or any sense of textual accuracy (with how Cervantes routinely denigrates his protagonist and makes him a laughingstock at his own expense). This has shaken me up, because if Don Quixote is merely a burlesque of a popular literary form from that specific period in Spanish history, then where is its universality? Where is its "mad truth"? These textual nerds are getting in the way of my gnostic interpretations of the book. What do I do? Please help /lit/!

>>21480301
"Kafka wishes to 'disenchant'Don Quixoteby making its protagonist a simple-minded yet curable man, sucked in by fantasy but not misled by it. The world that Sancho Panza returns to, by the end of Kafka's parable, isourworld. This is thus not so far from Milan Kundera's reading ofDon Quixote: that it is the great milestone of the beginning of 'modernity'. What could be more modern than disenchantment? If you see things shifting shapes, it is not that the world is enchanted, but thatyou are mad: the death of nature and the birth of the clinic at once.

Yet we might place the squire at the center of the action for reasons that Kafka does not seem to have detected. Who, after all, would violate the conventions to which Don Quixote himself is so faithful? A deceitful Moor, perhaps. And why? Because he isnotinterested in our world, but in spinning out spurious and false (or, to stick with neutral language, 'non-actual') ones. And why? Because he is a poet and not a historian. And why? Because, as Aristotle taught and as the Moors both learned and eventually passed on to the Christian universities of Iberia, it isthisuse of the narrative art that is closest to philosophy: to the investigation of the problems of metaphysics that the novel, properly conceived, invites us to consider. This is a fraught and morally treacherous investigation -- it invites us to entertain the false as true (or, again, to put it in neutral terms, to consider the non-actual as actual).

ForDon Quixote, who is perhaps the truly simple-minded character in the novel, knights-errant novels express the 'truth' in the sense of 'moral truth': they offer up a proper image of the way thingsshouldbe. But for someone involved in the production of the Don's tale, perhaps the Cide, offering up moral fables as truth is the greatest falsehood of all, and accordingly the proper response is to subvert the genre, via satire, and with an aim that is eminently philosophical: to destroy the pretense to truth of genre-conventional works by making the writing of fiction principally an exploration of the moral and metaphysical dimensions of recounting as true events that are strictly false."

From: https://www.berfrois.com/2015/05/on-cide-hamete-benengeli/

>Paladin of Souls and Vorkosigan saga by Lois McMaster Bujold

>The Empire Trilogy (1987-1992) by Janny Wurts
>Liveship Traders (1998-200) by Robin Hobb
>Birthgrave (1975-1978) by Tanith Lee
>Heart of Bronze (1997-1998) by Matthew Stover
>Karavans Trilogy (2006-2012) by Jennifer Roberson
>Skinwalkers (2014) by Wendy N. Wagner, about an ex-pirate Axe wielding mom!
>Frostfell (2006) by Mark Sehestedt
>Legacy of Steel (1998) by Mary H. Herbert
>The Traitor Spy Trilogy (2010-2012) by Trudi Canavan
>Sevenwaters Trilogy (1999-2001) by Juliet Marillier
>Blood songs (1987, third book in the Frost trilogy) by Robin Wayne Bailey
>Bloodsong Trilogy (1985-1986) by Asa Drake
>Gypsies (1988) by Robert Charles Wilson
>Child of Time (1991) by Robert Silverberg
>The Wayfarer Redemption (1995-1999) by Sara Douglass, by book three almost every character is pregnant, after book three there's a 20 year time-skip so all the mcs have grown-up children
>The Forgotten Beasts of Eld (1974) by Patricia A. McKillip
>The Keys to Paradise Trilogy (1987-1988) by Robert Vardeman, trio of mcs all of the same importance, veterans of the Trans-War that ravaged the country, one of them is a cat-girl who saves a slave kid and adopts him
>Bitter Angels (2009) by C.L Anderson
>The Great Wheel (1987, book three of the Tredana Trilogy) by Joyce Ballou Gregorian
>Daughter of the Bear King (1987) by Eleanor Arnason
>Night-Threads series by Ru Emerson, portal fantasy about a druggie mom, her sister and her teenage son.
>Frostflower adn Thorn (1980) Phyllis Ann Karr
>Fifth Millenium by S.M. Stirling, Shirley Meier, and Karen Wehrstein
>Spellsong Cycle (1997-2002) by L.E. Modesitt Jr
>The Sword of Lyric by Sharon Hinck, christian portal fantasy about a soccer mom and her son fighting against Not-Satan
>Cradle of Sea and Soill (2020) by Bernie Anes Paz

posts.com:
Is it me, or does modern fantasy lack soul? Think back to classical fantasy like Lord of the Rings, The Hobbit, The Wheel of Time, Le Morte De Arthur, The Once and Future King, Narnia, or Earthsea.
These books were dripping with soul and passion. They evoked a sense of wanderlust, adventure -- they were a gateway to another world rich with lore, heroes, villains, and universal themes such as hope, comradery, and love.
Now look at modern fantasy. Everything so fucking bleak and dreary. Everything has to be "gritty" and realistic. The colors are washed out, the protagonist is an asshole, the morals are vapid, and the wanderlust is gone.
Even the "lighter hearted" works like Sanderson are void of substance, since Sanderson seems more obsessed with anime and his magic systems, than telling a good story.

I finished By Fire Above and I feel as if I've felt for a bait and switch. The first book was pretty well paced and consistent action about airship combat in a Napoleonic Wars-like setting and it was pretty entertaining.

This book had 0 (zero) airship combat, despite being book 2 of the "Signal Airship" series, and instead placed the main characters on the ground for almost the entire novel. The first third of the book was dedicated to some stupid romance plot that never goes anywhere, though I presume it was supposed to be expanded on in a third book, and the latter two thirds are spent on the ground being shitty resistance fighters while the airship is only occasionally mentioned and barely featured. It was a complete disappointment of a sequel and I hope the author never puts out a third book since she's clearly missed what made the first one so exciting. I'd hate to see what nonsense she makes the next one about.

Death is itself an unknown state. We only know life, and the unknown is spooky to us. "Measure what is measurable, Make measurable what is unmeasurable." Death is our final frontier, as space becomes more and more infinite in this universe; we can only see what we can experience while we're alive. When we've observed the entire universe as a species, and left it, we'll truly understand it; we're doing that with the vast amounts of data we're getting from other planets and stars now. We'll either need Vast storage solutions and AI to share this information with each other in our short lives on the timeline, or live infinitely through death to see the full creation, expansion, and destruction of each universe to understand ours. Either way, science and religion don't have to fight.

tl;dr life is short. Enjoy it. Make others laugh, and smile, by making existence cozy for them. Be kind. Help people. You never know who just needed you to give them space, or to make them laugh. Next time, it could be you who needs a stranger's smile and a hand up.

>The 1948 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, T.S. Eliot is highly distinguished as a poet, a literary critic, a dramatist, an editor, and a publisher. In 1910 and 1911, while still a college student, he wrote “The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock,” published in Poetry magazine, and other poems that are landmarks in the history of modern literature. Eliot’s most notable works include The Waste Land (1922), Four Quartets (1943), and the play Murder in the Cathedral (1935). Eliot’s awards and honors include the British Order of Merit and the Nobel Prize for Literature. His play The Cocktail Party won the 1950 Tony Award for Best Play. In 1964, he was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Old Possum’s Book of Practical Cats was famously adapted in 1981 into the musical Cats, which won seven Tony Awards. Despite his enduring popularity, Eliot and his work have been criticized as having prejudiced views, particularly anti-Semitism.

Full biography here
https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/t-s-eliot

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I have to admit I wasn’t too impressed on my first read, but I felt urged to take it more seriously because it’s T.S. Eliot. The poem could be interpreted as many disparate memories of the writer or speaker, or perhaps some synthesized memories: “memory throws up high and dry a crowd of twisted things.” The smooth branch is immediately contrasted with a rusty spring: both are forms of decay, but one is organic and stiff like a skeleton, the other industrial and ready to break. This dichotomy is reversed between the streetlamp and the moon, where the latter is a natural body, but now weak, like a woman who suffered smallpox and its memory fading. The streetlamp is the arbiter of memory here, and is not even described as a product of industry or like anything else in the poem. It gives light - the moon is weak, and the sun isn’t there to nourish the geraniums. The lamp is a fatalistic drum beating against our periphery - they are everywhere, constantly observers of scenes like these: “I have seen eyes in the street / Trying to peer through lighted shutters.” Does everyone become like this because of artificial light? Do cities sap energy and life out of people? It’s not exactly a new observation. Sorry if any of this comes off as pseudointellectual, I’m not married to anything I wrote here myself.

>>21480605
>I read "Limonov" by Emmanuel Carrère and I loved it
Great book. Carrere basically just retold Limonov's books in chronological order, but his commentaries were kino whenever he had to accept that Limonov was right about many uncomfortable things. This passage in particular was the highlight of the book for me.
>>As much as I sincerely believe I’m incapable of gratuitous violence, I can also imagine, perhaps too readily, the reasons or circumstances that might have pushed me in other times toward Nazi collaboration, Stalinism, or the Chinese Cultural Revolution. Maybe on top of that I also tend to wonder too much if, among the values that are taken for granted in my surroundings, and which the people of my era, country, and social class believe unsurpassable, eternal, and universal, there aren't some that will one day appear grotesque, scandalous, or just plain wrong. When unsavory characters like Limonov and his kin say that our faith in human rights and democracy is the modern equivalent of Catholic colonialism--the same good intentions, the same absolute certitude in bringing truth, goodness, and beauty to the savages--I may not be pleased by this relativist argument, but I've got nothing solid to counter it with.
